title: Database Management
description: Learn database concepts, design principles, and basic operations for managing and analyzing data effectively.
subject: ict
achievementDescription: Complete database management module and understand how to organize and analyze data

text.introduction: Databases are essential for organizing, storing, and retrieving information in today's digital world. From school records to business operations, understanding database management helps create efficient systems for handling data. In Ghana's digital transformation, database skills are crucial for improving organizational efficiency and decision-making.

sections.title: Database Concepts and Design
sections.content: A database is an organized collection of data stored electronically. Data represents raw facts, while information is processed data that has meaning. Database Management Systems (DBMS) are software applications that manage databases. Different database types include relational databases (using tables), flat-file databases, and object-oriented databases. Entity-Relationship (ER) diagrams help visualize database structure.

sections.title: Database Operations
sections.content: Basic database operations include creating tables, entering data, querying information, and generating reports. Tables store data in rows (records) and columns (fields). Data entry involves inserting, updating, and deleting records. Queries retrieve specific information using criteria. Reports present data in organized, readable formats. Understanding these operations is essential for effective data management.

sections.title: Database Applications
sections.content: Databases have countless real-world applications including student record systems, inventory management, customer databases, and financial records. They support decision-making by providing organized access to information. Data analysis helps identify patterns and trends. Understanding database applications helps recognize opportunities to improve processes through better data organization.

questions.question: What is the difference between data and information?
options: Data is raw facts, information is processed data
Information is raw facts, data is processed
questions.explanation: Data refers to raw facts and figures, while information is data that has been processed, organized, and given meaning.

questions.question: What does DBMS stand for?
questions.explanation: DBMS stands for Database Management System, which is software that manages databases and provides tools for data manipulation.

questions.question: In a database table, what are the vertical columns called?
questions.explanation: In database tables, vertical columns are called fields, which define the type of data stored in each column.

questions.question: What is the purpose of a query in a database?

questions.explanation: A query is used to retrieve specific information from a database based on specified criteria or conditions.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a database application?
questions.explanation: A student record system is a database application that stores and manages student information like grades, attendance, and personal details.

exercises.title: Simple ER Diagram Design
exercises.instructions: Design simple Entity-Relationship diagrams for: a school library system, a small shop inventory, and a student registration system.
exercises.hint: Identify the main entities (like students, books, products) and their relationships. Use rectangles for entities and lines for relationships.

exercises.title: Table Structure Design
exercises.instructions: Design table structures for: a customer database, a product catalog, and an employee record system.
exercises.hint: Identify what fields each table needs. Consider data types (text, numbers, dates) and which fields are required.

exercises.title: Basic SELECT Statements
exercises.instructions: Write SQL SELECT statements to: find all students with grades above 80, list products with prices less than 100 cedis, and show employees hired after 2020.
exercises.hint: Use SELECT * FROM table_name WHERE condition. Remember to use appropriate comparison operators (> for greater than, < for less than).

exercises.title: Data Filtering Queries
exercises.instructions: Write queries to: find customers from Accra, list products in the 'Electronics' category, and show students in Grade 12.
exercises.hint: Use WHERE clauses with text comparisons. Remember that text values in SQL are usually enclosed in single quotes.

exercises.title: Database Operation Recognition
exercises.instructions: Identify whether each action is a CREATE, READ, UPDATE, or DELETE operation: adding a new student, viewing student grades, changing a student's address, and removing a student record.
exercises.hint: CREATE adds new data, READ retrieves data, UPDATE modifies existing data, and DELETE removes data.

exercises.title: Data Analysis Exercises
exercises.instructions: Analyze sample data to: calculate the average grade in a class, find the most expensive product, and count students in each grade level.
exercises.hint: Look for patterns in the data. For averages, sum all values and divide by the count. For maximums, find the highest value.

scenarioChallenges.title: Designing a Student Record System
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Your school needs a new student record system to replace the old paper-based system. The system should track student personal information, academic records, attendance, and fees. You need to design the database structure and plan how to implement it effectively.
tasks: Design the database tables needed for the student record system
Create an Entity-Relationship diagram showing table relationships
Plan the data entry process for new students
Design queries for common reports (attendance, grades, fees)
Consider data security and access control requirements
learningObjectives: Apply database design principles to real-world systems
Plan for data management and reporting
Connect database design to organizational needs
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Many Ghanaian schools are transitioning from paper-based to digital record systems. Understanding database design can help improve school administration efficiency and provide better access to student information for teachers and administrators.

scenarioChallenges.title: Managing Inventory for a Shop
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Your family owns a small shop selling household goods and groceries. The current inventory system is disorganized, leading to stock-outs and overstocking. You want to create a simple database system to track products, monitor stock levels, and generate reports for better business management.
tasks: Design inventory tables for products, suppliers, and transactions
Plan how to track stock levels and reorder points
Create queries for low stock alerts and sales reports
Design a simple data entry interface for daily operations
Plan for regular data backup and maintenance
learningObjectives: Apply database concepts to business operations
Plan for data maintenance and backup
Connect technology solutions to business needs
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Small businesses are the backbone of Ghana's economy. Understanding how to implement simple database systems can help local shop owners improve their operations, reduce waste, and increase profitability.

scenarioChallenges.title: Using Databases for Agricultural Record Keeping
scenarioChallenges.scenario: Your village farming cooperative wants to improve their record-keeping system. They need to track crop yields, weather data, fertilizer usage, and market prices to make better farming decisions. You want to design a database system that can help with this agricultural planning.
tasks: Design database tables for farming data (crops, weather, inputs, yields)
Create queries for analyzing crop performance trends
Plan data collection methods for rural farming communities
Design reports for seasonal planning and market analysis
Consider how to make the system accessible to farmers with limited computer skills
learningObjectives: Apply database design to agricultural applications
Create data analysis and reporting systems
Plan for data collection in different environments
scenarioChallenges.ghanaContext: Agriculture is a major sector in Ghana's economy. Using databases for agricultural record-keeping can help farmers make better decisions, improve crop yields, and access market information, contributing to food security and economic development.
